comment: Strategic in the same way that you might find Blackjack or Poker. Like, sure, you can increase your changes of success by careful deduction of the cards, but at the end of the day, the game is still incredibly luck-driven, oftentimes far beyond your control, and almost inevitably turns into damage control and mitigating point loss (unless it's one of those rounds where you get lucky and happen upon all the cards you need), which may very well be by design, but doesn't strike me as particularly clever or even fun. The most interesting aspect is the time crunch—i.e., paying attention to how many card draws are left (including the cards on the display), juxtaposing that with how many card lays you'd ideally like to make, and watching as those two metrics traverse in opposite directions. Mostly, though, my games of this have felt like a bit of a slog despite how quick it plays, which isn't a good sign.

GAMEPLAY
Lost Cities is a 2P lane-battler. The choices are to either discard a card or play a card from hand to a lane, making sure that cards are arranged in ascending order. Then, draw a new card either from the deck or a discard pile. By committing to a lane, you’re starting at -20 VP so you need to make sure you can get it in the black to earn points.

THOUGHTS
Lost Cities is dead simple, making for a solid game to play with family or a something casual for the pub. It’s a game where distractions or interruptions won’t matter much to the flow, but you can also play as competitively as you like. The multiplier cards add a fun twist, especially if a player ends up multiplying a negative score. But, otherwise, Lost Cities asks players to manage their hands well and be smart about discarding at the right moment. Simple and smooth, but with enough to think about to keep players engaged.

PnP - Redesign

1) Go on lucrative expeditions by melding cards.
2) Every turn, you play a card (numbered 2-10) to one of your expeditions or to its corresponding color's discard stack, and draw a card either from the draw pile or from one of the 5 discard stacks. You may only play cards to expeditions in ascending order. 3 wager cards for each color can be played before any number card has been played in that expedition. These double, triple, and quadruple your score in that expedition. Starting an expedition costs 20 points, so if you don't think you can overcome this deficit, don't start that expedition!
3) I loved: How quick it plays, how the simple rules allow for creative moves (throwing a low card into a discard pile from an expedition you intent to double down on in order to entice a player to start it, or throwing a low card in order to entice a player to stop waiting for wagers). This in addition to the player-controlled tempo of the game, and the satisfaction from unloading all of your cards in the last few turns to overturn the score. Great little filler.
4) Could be improved: Not necessarily a con, but the game does have a considerable luck element (which is much more pronounced than its sibling, Schotten Totten).
5) A great, super-fast filler. The reviewer who said this is the espresso of games was very accurate in their description. I am late to the party on this, having only recently started playing this on BGA. Suffice to say, I am hooked.

Lost Cities is an easy to understand card game for two players. You want to place cards of the same color in ascending order - you are allowed to leave gaps, which cannot be filled later on - in your half of the playing area. But if you start a color, you'll get negative 20 points which you have to beat with that color to get positive points out of it. You can also play betting cards for the respective colors, which will multiply your points if you succeed in getting positive points. Otherwise, it will multiply your negative points.
The game is very much about risk management. You have to think about which cards you can still get and which cards you want to play in the common middle area to buy some time while also giving your opponent the opportunity to take them.
The game is easy to understand but has a good strategic element as well. Very nice two-player game.
The only thing I dislike is the counting of the points at the end of the game. That requires doing some math.
Very nice hand management. You will get a dozen plays of finding new little strategic quirks.

I think it's "easier" to make a good complex game than a good simple one. You can just layer systems in a complex way that can give that Skinner Box-like dopamine fix at fairly frequent intervals in a complex game. In a simple game, the core mechanism has to be compelling and stand up to repeated plays without growing wearisome. Few games exemplify this better than Lost Cities. The game is happening not just by what card your opponent plays (or is conspicuously not playing), but also on their face when they draw cards. You yourself are going to need an Alka-Seltzer after practically every turn as you try to deduce which paths you should keep hoping for and which you should give up on AND which cards you absolutely cannot let your opponent have. It's just so good. There is obviously luck in the card draw, but a better player will consistently win in this game, and that isn't because of luck. It's just a solid design.

My favorite short 2-player game from one of our favorite game designers: Reiner Knizia. Easy rules, short playing time and although it has a big luck factor, as most card games do, it requires a lot of tactical decisions to be made because starting an expedition costs 20 minus points. Are you going to wait one more round or are you going to put your card in the middle, maybe helping your opponent, or are you going to start to explore anyway, knowing that you're next card drawn will be the card you needed but cannot play anymore now... so easy but so frustrating! A cool card game that we always take on holidays with us!

We also own Keltis, based on the same principle, but that is less forcing you to play your cards as Lost Cities does.
